item.title: Report X-2025071370
item.description:
Report X-2025071370

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-07-16
  • City: SAUK VILLAGE
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ABF FREIGHT SYSTEM, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: ABF stated when they were unloading they noticed one 50 lb bag of UN3378 was torn in transit due to the pallet tearing the bag. ABF stated roughly 2 lbs has spilled onto the trailer floor. No other surfaces were effected. A crew from Response Management Services (RMS) arrived onsite. The crew report ed approximately 2 pounds of UN3378 released to the interior of trailer 89202. RMS personnel utilized hand tools to collect the hydroponic finisher and the pigment powder. All hydroponic finisher-impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon poly drum and the pigment powder- impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and staged for further management.

  • City: DOLTON

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: When Driver returned to facility and was getting ready to unload he opened the doors and noticed that the floor was wet and material began dripping from the back of the trailer onto the pavement @1500ct. The driver then notified his manager and absorbents were set down to collect any free liquid. The internal response team was called to address the clean-up. They collected the materials needed to address the clean up and began transferring the material to another tote @1600ct. While transferring the material they laid more absorbents down to collect and begin cleaning up the material that had gotten on the pavement and the floor of the trailer. Approximately 10-15 gallons was released. Once the damaged tote was emptied they cut it up and repackaged it for disposal. The clean up was complete @1945ct.

  • Description: At 0028 ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at BCH. It was reported that approximately 5 gallons of battery acid released from a 2105-pound commercial battery due to improper loading and blocking and bracing by terminal BGB. The release impacted trailer # 3233736 and the concrete under the trailer at dock door 136. Absorbents and noodles have been placed to prevent migration to the drains. Mike stated that Dion with Clean Harbors already agreed to assist with the cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 10-gallons of UN2794 Battery Acid released to the wooden trailer floor and concrete dock floor due to improper loading / blocking & bracing. The contractors cleaned and neutralized the trailer floor and concrete dock floor and transferred the products to new pallets. The waste was containerized to (4) 55-gallon poly drums with battery acid and impacted soda ash and (1) 275-gallon tote with battery acid and impacted rinse water. The 2100-pound battery was placed on a skid. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: t 20:28 PM ET, with BCH contacted the call center to report a spill that occurred inside of a trailer in Chicago Heights, IL. The spill consists of approximately half a gallon of Zep Industrial Purple Degreaser & Cleaner, which was released from 4-1-gallon plastic jugs due to other freight being double stacked on top of the containers, crushing them and spilling onto the trailer floor. ERTS will dispatch a contractor to assist, as this is a corrosive material. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately .5-gallon of UN3266 Zep products released to a 1x1 area of the wooden trailer floor due to improper loading. The contractors cleaned and neutralized with Simple Green and oil dry. The (2) bottles of Zep Industrial Purple Degreaser & Cleaner were placed in 55-gallon poly drum, (3) bottles of Zep Neutral pH Floor Cleaner were placed in 55-gallon poly drum, (4) bottles of Zep All Purpose Cleaner were placed in 55-gallon poly drum, (3) bottles of Zep House and Siding Pressure wash were placed in a 55-gallon poly drum. The impacted oil dry and PPE were containerized to a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 9265
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractors arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 6ft-by-6ft area of the trailer floor and concrete floor and estimated that five (5) gallons of material were released due to unknown reasons from one (1) 55-gallon metal drum. Clean Harbors personnel had a technician bring out SCBA gear for the clean-up. Absorbent pads were applied to the affected areas and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The damaged drum was overpacked into one (1) 65-gallon poly overpack. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: At 2220 ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at BCH. It was reported that approximately 55 gallons of Ancamine AEP released from a 55-gallon DM due to a forklift puncture. The release impacted trailer # 3193150 and the concrete outside at dock door 191. Oil dri was placed for containment. Mike stated that it has gone into the drain that goes to the retention pond. ERTS will proceed to dispatch a contractor to the site to complete cleanup activities. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 55-gallons of UN2815 Ancamine AEP product released to a 150x100 area impacting the wood trailer floor, concrete underneath trailer and storm drain/retention pound due to a forklift puncture. The team used a skid vac to containerize approximately 2 to 3 gallons of residual product from the drain. This waste was solidified and containerized inside one of the (10) 55-gallon poly drums along with spent absorbent and debris. The team overpacked (1) 55-gallon poly drum into a 95-gallon poly drum. The waste was stated onsite for terminal personnel to manage.
